list_page_teaser: American Presidents, just like any other group of individuals, have different personalities.  Learn how the images of some popular and recent presidents reflect their idealism, decisiveness, and other qualities.
description_html:
Which politicians – ☺ if any ☺ – are your favorites? How does your personality compare to theirs?

This gallery contains some spiritual portraits of our presidents, past, recent, and present. If you know your four-letter type, you can easily answer these questions for yourself!
story_html:
I frequently wonder whether an individual's personality type has any bearing on how they lean politically. As an idealist, I can say that I, for one, definitely admire the more idealistic presidents, such as Jefferson and Lincoln, the most.

For a few of these images, I consulted with one or more friends while going through the Questionnaire in David Keirsey's Please Understand Me. For many of the others I used the type from his book, Presidential Temperament, and created a generic image using the same fixed percentages (58%/42%) as those used to make the generic images in the Sixteen Types gallery. (The graphs that appear beneath each image make it easy to see which process I used to create it.)

If this topic interests you, definitely check out David Keirsey's book. It covers this topic in depth!

image_list.title: George Washington
image_list.subtitle_html: 1st President of the USA - Apr. 30, 1789 to Mar. 4, 1797
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Green and Yellow in this spiritual portrait of George Washington shows that he was a strong leader.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
In his book Please Understand Me II, David Keirsey picks George Washington to represent the archetypal ESTJ. His decisiveness, realism, and attention to details served him well during difficult times, such as those at Valley Forge.

Note that this is a 'generic' image, based on fixed percentages.
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Washington's rationality.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  He was a strong leader and his tendency to be logical enabled him to keep a cool head during the many trials and difficulties he expereicned in leading the Continental Army during the American Revolution.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Washington's tendency to be down-to-earth.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  Being able to keep track of things like the number of men and the supplies they would need contributed greatly to his ability to be a great leader.

image_list.title: Thomas Jefferson
image_list.subtitle_html: 3rd President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1801 to Mar. 4, 1809
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue and Green in this portrait of Thomas Jefferson shows that he was a logical thinker and open to new ideas.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
I find Jefferson to be remarkable in many ways, certainly at least in part because his name was the same as mine ('Tom') and he was from Virginia (where I grew up). David Keirsey identifies Jefferson as an INTP, and that certainly seems reasonable to me.

Although we should all be familiar with the Declaration of Independence, a letter he wrote to Maria Cosway in the spring of 1786 articulates quite well the distinction between Thinking (Green) and Feeling (Red) functions in these four-letter-types.

Entitled My Head and My Heart, it demonstrates how he was well aware of, and struggled with, the dichotomy between reason and emotion over a century before Carl Jung wrote about them in his book, General Description of the Types. This is a wonderful letter, and I strongly encourage you to read it!

Note that this is a portrait of a 'generic' INTP, and is based on fixed percentages. Based on this letter I believe that Jefferson's F-T score on the quiz could be closer to 50%/50% than the 58%/42% shown here.
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Jefferson's tendency to be logical.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  This preference is evident in his interests in topics such as philosophy, science, and technology.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Jefferson's idealism.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  This tendency is evident in his authoring of the Declaration of Independence and his support of religious freedom and being able to see the possibility that people with different religious beliefs could overcome their differences and learn to live together.

image_list.title: Abraham Lincoln
image_list.subtitle_html: 16th President of the USA - Mar. 4, 1861 to Apr. 15, 1865
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue and Green in this portrait of Abraham Lincoln show that he was, like Jefferson, a logical person and open to new ideas.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
David Keirsey identifies Abraham Lincoln as an INTP, and this is certainly reasonable.

His Idealism is evident in his speeches, such as the Gettysburg Address. In this short speech he shows how his temperament is similar to Jefferson's by reiterating the important principles outlined in Jefferson's Declaration of Independence.

One of the most famous phrases in this speech, in which Lincoln declares that government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth certainly shows his ability to see a possibile future that many others obviously had difficulty comprehending.

Note that this is an image of a 'generic' personality, and is based on fixed percentages.
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Lincoln's preference for logic over emotion.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  His ability to reason logically surely served him well during the days he spent as a lawyer.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Lincoln's iNtuition.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  He is certainly most famous for his ability to see the possibility of the United States as being a country without slaves.

image_list.title: George Herbert Walker Bush
image_list.subtitle_html: 41st President of the USA - Jan. 20, 1989 to Jan. 20 1993
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The preponderance of Green in this spiritual portrait of George Herbert Walker Bush (George W.'s father) shows that he is a very logical thinker.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
When I wrote the original version of this program in the late 1980s, sometimes I would get with some friends and we would answer the questions in the Keirsey Temperament Sorter, guessing how famous people would answer them. I used the results of one of these exercises to create this portrait of George H. W. Bush, the 41st president — father of and not to be confused with George W. Bush, the 43rd president.

It is extremely important to note that unlike many of the other presidents' images this one is not based on fixed percentages, but rather based on the impression he made at the time on my friends and me. We perceived that he was extremely logical, and this image reflects that by containing a preponderance of Green.

It is interesting to compare this image to the one of Mr. Spock, Chief Scientist of Star Trek's USS Enterprise.
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Bush's preference for being down-to-earth.  In Introverts, the dominant function is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  This ability to pay attention to details served him well in his work in the military, business, and the many government posts he held prior to being elected president.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Bush's preference for logic and rationality.  In Introverts, the auxiliary function is directed outwardly and is more evident than the dominant function.  It is clear from this image that he was a very logical individual!

image_list.title: Bill Clinton
image_list.subtitle_html: 42nd President of the USA - Jan. 20, 1993 to Jan. 20, 2001
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: There is some disagreement regarding Bill Clinton's personality type, but at least one article claims he is 'verified' as an ENFP.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
This image is based on an article at personalitydesk.com that claimed Bill Clinton is an ENFP. This article is no longer online, but this article at truity.com claims that he is verified as an ENFP (whatever that means).

Digging a bit deeper though reveals there is no real consensus about Bill's type. David Keirsey claims he is an ESFP while this article at babble.com claims he is an ESFJ. In an effort to resolve the uncertainty, an article at celebritytypes.com also argues that Bill is an ESFP (and not an ENFP). But I thought he was verified as an ENFP!?!

This is clearly a controversial issue, and it makes me think that not everyone conforms to a single personality type 100% of the time. I, for one, consider myself to be extremely flexible and I enjoy fitting into different roles as the situation warrants it.

Some people change as they age, and some people like to exercise their flexibility and choose to use the abilities most suited for our current environment. And as a matter of fact, I tend to do both! However introspection and mindfulness over the years has led me to think I am most comfortable being an INFP.

It is entirely possible that Bill has equal, or nearly equal, preferences when it comes to choosing between pairs of opposites. As the scales that accompany each image show – except for those that are based on just the four-letter-type, and hence use fixed percentages, of course – some people have stronger preferences than others.

In my experience, this is entirely reasonable and not at all uncommon. This is why I emphasize it when presenting images that are 'generic,' due to having only the four-letter-type available.

And this image, being based on a four-letter-type, is one of those images of a 'generic' personality, that as a result uses fixed percentages.
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Clinton's iNtuition.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  His preference for embracing possibilities surely contributed to the fact that he presided over a long period of peacetime economic expansion.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Clinton's preference for making judgements using his emotions.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  In Bill's case, allowing his heart to rule over his head certainly contributed to his fooling around with women who were not his wife, ultimately leading to his being impeached.

image_list.title: George W. Bush
image_list.subtitle_html: 43rd President of the USA - Jan. 20, 2001 to Jan. 20, 2009
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: A frequently-referenced article (see the Story for the link) claims that George W. Bush is an ESTP.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
This frequently-referenced article at slate.com claims that George W. Bush is an ESTP, and that seems reasonable. As is the case with other recent presidents, however, searching the internet can lead to finding results with differing opinions.

This leaves us to decide – or not – what we want to believe for our own selves.

The article mentioned previously also claims that [ESTPs] are a common presidential type: Both Roosevelts, JFK, and LBJ were ESTPs.

Note that this image is based on a four-letter-type and is therefore a 'generic' image, based on fixed percentages.
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Bush's preference for facts over ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.  This preference explains why he would choose to study business at Harvard, and his very practical desire to cut taxes.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Bush's preference for logic over emotion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.  This preference explains his willingness to wage wars in foreign countries with the goal of protecting American interests, because an idealist would probably seek more peaceful solutions.

image_list.title: Barack Obama
image_list.subtitle_html: 44th President of the USA - Jan. 20, 2009 to Jan. 20, 2017
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: The Blue and Red in this spiritual portrait of Barack Obama shows that he is open to new possibilities and desires harmonious human relationships.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.story_html:
This frequently-referenced article at slate.com claims Barack Obama is an ENFP, and that seems reasonable. As is the case with other recent presidents, however, searching the internet can lead to finding results with differing opinions, including one explaining why he's an ENTP and one claiming he's probably an INTJ Mastermind.

This leaves us to decide – or not – what we want to believe for our own selves. For my purposes, it is sufficient to know that all of these claim he is iNtuitive, because that is a preference found in two of my favorite presidents, Jefferson and Lincoln.

In support of the claims that he is iNtuitive, we have his idealism, hope for the future, and his concern for others, which are all evident in his determination to pass legislation making health care available to all people.

Note that this image is based on a four-letter-type and is therefore a 'generic' image, based on fixed percentages.
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait of represents Obama's idealism and hope for the future.  In Extraverts, the dominant function is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Obama's preference for using emotions more than logic to make decisions.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary function is directed inwardly and is less evident than the dominant function.
